div.l: And thoght al this is done but for a wyle
They wene that no man̄ may hem be gile
But be my thrift ȝit shal I bler͗e her yee
For al her sleiȝt and her Phylosophy
The more queynt Crekis that þey make
The more wol I stele when I take
In stede of flour͗e ȝit wol ȝeve hem bren̄
The grettest Clerkis be nat wisest men̄
As whylom̄ to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of al her art ne count I nat a tare
Out atte dor he goith ful pryvyly
When̄ þat he sawe hys tyme softely
He lokith vp and down̄ til he hath found
These Clerkis hors wher͗e þey stode I bound
Be hynd the myl vndir a leffel
And to the hors he goith feir͗e and wele
He stripith of the bridillis right Anon̄
And when̄ the hors was louse he gan̄ goon̄
Toward þe feld where wild maris renne
And forth with wy he þorowe thik and thyn̄
This myller goith aȝene no word he seid
But doith his note and with þe Clerkis pleyd
Til that her corn was feir͗e ⁊and wele I ground
And when̄ the mele is sakkid and I bound
This Iohn goith forth and fynt his hors a wey
And gan to cry harowe and wel a wey
Our͗e hors is lost aleyn̄ for Cokkis baonysbonysbanys
Step out thy feet com̄ out attonys
Alas our͗e warden̄ hath his palfrey lorn̄
This aleyn̄ al forgate both mele ⁊and corn̄
Al was out of mynd his husbondry
What whilk wey is he goon̄ he gan̄ to cry
The wyfe cam leping inward with a ren̄
She seid alas your͗e hors goith to the fen̄
With wild maris as fast as he may go
Vn thank come on his hond þat bond hem so
